Make Topping: Toss together crumbs, cheeses, and oil until combined well. Sprinkle topping evenly over greens mixture and bake in oven until crumbs are golden and mixture is bubbling, about 30 minutes.
Toss together crumbs, cheeses, and oil until combined well. Sprinkle topping evenly over greens mixture and bake in oven until crumbs are golden and mixture is bubbling, about 30 minutes.
Cooks' Notes: The best way to make coarse fresh breadcrumbs is to cube fresh bread, then grind it in small batches in a blender (a food processor is not as good at grinding crusty bread into breadcrumbs because the crusts get stuck in the blade). Creamy lamb's-quarters mixture and crumb mixture can be made 1 day ahead and kept separately in airtight containers, chilled.
The best way to make coarse fresh breadcrumbs is to cube fresh bread, then grind it in small batches in a blender (a food processor is not as good at grinding crusty bread into breadcrumbs because the crusts get stuck in the blade).
Creamy lamb's-quarters mixture and crumb mixture can be made 1 day ahead and kept separately in airtight containers, chilled.
ingredients: 1 cup milk, plus additional, if necessary
1 cup coarse fresh breadcrumbs (coarsely ground from a baguette; see Cooks' Notes)
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat the oven to 350° F with the rack in the middle.
Butter a 2-quart shallow baking dish.
Bring 1-inch salted water to a boil in a large saucepan.
Wash approximately 120 g of lamb's-quarters in cold water and drain well.
Trim any coarse, woody stems from the lamb's-quarters.
Add lamb's-quarters to the boiling water and cook over medium heat, covered, until leaves are wilted and stems are tender, about 2 to 3 minutes.
Drain the greens in a sieve or colander and rinse under cold running water.
Drain again, pressing out excess liquid with the back of a spoon.
Coarsely chop the greens and transfer to a bowl.
In the reserved saucepan, cook 30 g of chopped scallions in 0.20 tbsp of olive oil with a pinch of salt over medium heat, stirring, until softened, about 3 to 4 minutes.
Combine scallion mixture with greens in the bowl.
Melt 0.20 oz of butter in the reserved saucepan over medium-low heat and stir in 0.20 oz of flour.
Cook, stirring, for 2 minutes, then whisk in 0.07 cup of milk and bring to a boil, whisking.
Reduce heat and simmer the sauce, whisking, for 2 minutes until thick.
Remove from heat and whisk in a pinch of nutmeg, 0.20 tsp of lemon zest, and salt and pepper to taste.
Mix the sauce into the greens mixture.
If the mixture is too thick, thin with a little additional milk; season with salt and pepper.
Spread out the mixture in the baking dish.
Toss together 0.20 cup of breadcrumbs, 0.10 cup of mozzarella, and 0.05 cup of Parmesan with 0.27 tbsp of olive oil until combined well.
Sprinkle topping evenly over the greens mixture.
Bake in the oven until crumbs are golden and mixture is bubbling, about 30 minutes.

original_instructions:
For the onion marmellata, place a large, heavy pot over medium-high heat. Add the olive oil and the onions. Stir to combine and cook until starting to sizzle, about 2 minutes. Add the remaining ingredients. Reduce the heat to low. Cover the pot and cook over low heat for 2 hours, stirring every 30 minutes to scrape up any brown bits. The onions should be a soft, jam-like consistency and a deep mahogany color.
Meanwhile, for the pork chops, combine the rosemary, thyme, garlic, salt, and pepper in a small bowl. Using your fingers, work all the ingredients together until well combined. Rub the herb mixture over the pork chops. Cover with plastic wrap and reserve in the refrigerator.
About 20 minutes before the onions are finished, remove the pork chops from the refrigerator. Place a grill pan over medium-high heat or preheat a gas or charcoal grill. Grill the pork chops to medium, about 7 minutes a side depending on thickness. To serve, spoon the onion marmellata over the pork chops. Sprinkle with the chopped parsley. Serve immediately.
step_by_step_instructions: Place a large, heavy pot over medium-high heat.
Add 1 tablespoon of olive oil and 200 grams of thinly sliced onions.
Stir to combine and cook until starting to sizzle, about 2 minutes.

Add 1 tablespoon of orange marmalade, 0.25 tablespoon of chopped rosemary, 0.25 tablespoon of chopped thyme, 0.25 teaspoon of kosher salt, 0.25 teaspoon of black pepper, 0.5 tablespoon of balsamic vinegar, and 0.25 tablespoon of sugar.
Reduce the heat to low.
Cover the pot and cook over low heat for 2 hours, stirring every 30 minutes to scrape up any brown bits.
Meanwhile, combine 0.25 tablespoon of chopped rosemary, 0.25 tablespoon of chopped thyme, 0.5 clove of minced garlic, 0.25 teaspoon of kosher salt, and 0.25 teaspoon of black pepper in a small bowl.
Using your fingers, work all the ingredients together until well combined.
Rub the herb mixture over 1 pork chop.
Cover with plastic wrap and reserve in the refrigerator.
About 20 minutes before the onions are finished, remove the pork chop from the refrigerator.
Place a grill pan over medium-high heat or preheat a grill.
Grill the pork chop to medium, about 7 minutes on each side depending on thickness.
To serve, spoon the onion marmellata over the pork chop.
Sprinkle with 0.25 tablespoon of chopped parsley.
Serve immediately.

original_instructions:
Finely slice the peppers and onions. Make a paste out of the garlic and 1 teaspoon of salt. Seed and slice the Scotch bonnet pepper, dice the tomatoes and set them aside. Soften the onions and peppers in the sunflower oil over high heat for 5 minutes, stirring frequently. Add the pasted garlic, Scotch bonnet pepper, tomatoes, and dry seasonings and cook for another 10 minutes over medium heat, stirring frequently. Add the tomato paste, cook for another minute or so, then remove from the heat. Blend the mixture with a generous 3/4 cup of chicken stock. If this was prepared in advance, reheat it first. Add another 3/4 cup of stock and blend until the mixture is smooth. Add the palm oil, a final teaspoon of salt, and then pour 2 1/2 cups of this mixture back into the pot. Heat the sauce until it is lightly bubbling. Measure out your rice, then add to the pot. The pot should have a tight-fitting lid, but if it doesn’t you can use some foil with the shiny side facing down to retain the heat. Stir gently so that all the rice is coated with the red sauce, then reduce the heat to a very low flame—the lowest possible. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Open the lid and stir gently again. It is important to get under the center of the pan so all the rice cooks at the same rate. Cover and simmer for another 10 minutes. Open and stir for a final time, then simmer for a final 10 minutes. This makes 30 minutes cooking time in total. Turn the heat off and allow to steam, covered, for another 15 minutes. It’s tempting to open the pot here but it’s very important to trust the process and allow the rice to cook residually. This improves the final taste and texture of the rice. Open the lid then leave to stand for 5 minutes, uncovered. Then fluff with a fork to separate the rice, slowly working inward from the edge of the pan in a swirling motion. If the rice is not completely cooked, add the remaining 1/2 cup stock, stir gently, then place back over low heat for another 10 minutes. Spoon the rice out onto a separate dish and serve.
Finely slice the peppers and onions. Make a paste out of the garlic and 1 teaspoon of salt. Seed and slice the Scotch bonnet pepper, dice the tomatoes and set them aside. Soften the onions and peppers in the sunflower oil over high heat for 5 minutes, stirring frequently. Add the pasted garlic, Scotch bonnet pepper, tomatoes, and dry seasonings and cook for another 10 minutes over medium heat, stirring frequently. Add the tomato paste, cook for another minute or so, then remove from the heat.
Blend the mixture with a generous 3/4 cup of chicken stock. If this was prepared in advance, reheat it first. Add another 3/4 cup of stock and blend until the mixture is smooth. Add the palm oil, a final teaspoon of salt, and then pour 2 1/2 cups of this mixture back into the pot. Heat the sauce until it is lightly bubbling. Measure out your rice, then add to the pot. The pot should have a tight-fitting lid, but if it doesn’t you can use some foil with the shiny side facing down to retain the heat. Stir gently so that all the rice is coated with the red sauce, then reduce the heat to a very low flame—the lowest possible.
Cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Open the lid and stir gently again. It is important to get under the center of the pan so all the rice cooks at the same rate. Cover and simmer for another 10 minutes. Open and stir for a final time, then simmer for a final 10 minutes. This makes 30 minutes cooking time in total. Turn the heat off and allow to steam, covered, for another 15 minutes. It’s tempting to open the pot here but it’s very important to trust the process and allow the rice to cook residually. This improves the final taste and texture of the rice.
Open the lid then leave to stand for 5 minutes, uncovered. Then fluff with a fork to separate the rice, slowly working inward from the edge of the pan in a swirling motion. If the rice is not completely cooked, add the remaining 1/2 cup stock, stir gently, then place back over low heat for another 10 minutes. Spoon the rice out onto a separate dish and serve.
step_by_step_instructions: Finely slice 1 red bell pepper and 1/2 an onion.
Make a paste out of 1 bulb of garlic and 1/2 teaspoon salt.
Seed and slice 1/8 of a Scotch bonnet pepper, dice 15 g of plum tomatoes and set them aside.
Soften the sliced onions and peppers in 1 tablespoon sunflower oil over high heat for 5 minutes, stirring frequently.
Add the garlic paste, Scotch bonnet pepper, tomatoes, and 1/4 teaspoon each of dried thyme, ground ginger, cayenne pepper, and smoked paprika to the pot.
Cook for another 10 minutes over medium heat, stirring frequently.
Add 1/4 teaspoon tomato paste, cook for another minute or so, then remove from the heat.
Blend the mixture with 1/4 cup chicken stock until smooth. If the mixture was prepared in advance, reheat it first.
Add another 1/4 cup of chicken stock and blend until the mixture is smooth.
Add 1/4 teaspoon red palm oil and a final 1/4 teaspoon salt to the mixture, then pour 3/4 cup of this mixture back into the pot.
Heat the sauce until it is lightly bubbling.
Measure out 1/3 cup white basmati rice, then add it to the pot.
Stir gently so that all the rice is coated with the red sauce, then reduce the heat to the lowest possible flame.
Cover and simmer for 10 minutes.
Open the lid and stir gently again, ensuring to stir under the center of the pan.
Cover and simmer for another 10 minutes.
Open the lid and stir for a final time, then simmer for a final 10 minutes.
Turn the heat off and allow to steam, covered, for another 15 minutes.
Open the lid and leave to stand for 5 minutes, uncovered.
Fluff the rice with a fork to separate it, working inward from the edge of the pan in a swirling motion.
If the rice is not completely cooked, add the remaining 1/6 cup chicken stock, stir gently, then place back over low heat for another 10 minutes.
Spoon the rice out onto a separate dish and serve.

original_instructions:
1. For the rub: Mix the five-spice powder, 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, granulated garlic, and onion powder together in a bowl. Smear the spices all over the drumsticks. Cover and refrigerate for several hours or overnight.
2. Prepare an outdoor grill with a medium-hot fire on one side of the grill for both direct and indirect cooking. Position a drip pan under the grate on the cool side. Toss 1/2 cup soaked wood chips onto the coals.
3. Lay the turkey legs on the grate over the drip pan. Cover the grill and position the lid's vent holes directly over the meat. When the fire dies down, after 45 minutes or so, add about a 1/2 dozen pieces of cold charcoal and the remaining wood chips to maintain a medium to medium-low smoky fire.
4. Meanwhile, make the mop: Whisk together the garlic, ginger, vinegar, soy sauce, sesame oil, hoisin, chili sauce, and scallions.
5. Set aside about half the sauce for serving. After about 1 hour, mop the turkey drumsticks with some of the mop and flip. Mop and flip every 10 minutes or so until the legs are browned and glazed and an instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the thigh registers about 170 degrees F, 30 to 40 minutes more. Serve the drumsticks with the reserved mop on the side.
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper
1 1/2-inches fresh ginger, peeled and finely chopped
4 teaspoons Asian chili sauce, such as Sriracha
4 scallions (white and green parts), thinly sliced
step_by_step_instructions: Mix 0.5 tablespoon of five-spice powder, 0.125 teaspoon of salt, 0.0625 teaspoon of pepper, 0.125 teaspoon of granulated garlic, and 0.125 teaspoon of onion powder together in a bowl.
Smear the spices all over 1 turkey drumstick.
Cover and refrigerate for several hours or overnight.
Prepare an outdoor grill with a medium-hot fire on one side for both direct and indirect cooking.
Position a drip pan under the grate on the cool side.
Toss 0.1875 cup soaked wood chips onto the coals.
Lay the turkey leg on the grate over the drip pan.
Cover the grill and position the lid's vent holes directly over the meat.
When the fire dies down after about 45 minutes, add about 1.5 pieces of cold charcoal and 0.0625 cup wood chips to maintain a medium to medium-low smoky fire.

Whisk together 0.5 tablespoon of chopped garlic, 0.375 inches of chopped ginger, 0.1875 cup of rice vinegar, 0.0625 cup of soy sauce, 0.25 teaspoon of sesame oil, 0.5 tablespoon of hoisin sauce, 1 teaspoon of Asian chili sauce, and 1 sliced scallion.
Set aside half the sauce for serving.
After about 1 hour, mop the turkey drumstick with some of the mop and flip.
Mop and flip every 10 minutes until the leg is browned and glazed and an instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part registers about 170 degrees F, 30 to 40 minutes more.
Serve the drumstick with the reserved mop on the side.

recipe_title: Spice-Rubbed Lamb Chops with Roasted Tomatoes
original_instructions:
Preheat oven to 450°F. and lightly oil a baking pan. Arrange tomatoes in one layer in prepared pan and brush with 1 teaspoon oil. Roast tomatoes in middle of oven 20 minutes, or until browned lightly, and keep warm. Pat lamb chops dry. In a small dish stir together cumin, salt, and pepper and rub mixture on both sides of lamb chops. In a 9-inch heavy non-stick skillet heat remaining 2 teaspoons oil over moderate heat until hot but not smoking and cook lamb chops 3 to 5 minutes on each side for medium-rare meat. Transfer lamb chops to 2 plates and serve with roasted tomatoes.
Preheat oven to 450°F. and lightly oil a baking pan.
Arrange tomatoes in one layer in prepared pan and brush with 1 teaspoon oil. Roast tomatoes in middle of oven 20 minutes, or until browned lightly, and keep warm.
Pat lamb chops dry. In a small dish stir together cumin, salt, and pepper and rub mixture on both sides of lamb chops.
In a 9-inch heavy non-stick skillet heat remaining 2 teaspoons oil over moderate heat until hot but not smoking and cook lamb chops 3 to 5 minutes on each side for medium-rare meat. Transfer lamb chops to 2 plates and serve with roasted tomatoes.
ingredients: 3 plum tomatoes, cut lengthwise into 1/4-inch-thick slices
two 3/4-to 1-inch-thick shoulder lamb chops (8 to 10 ounces each)
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat oven to 450°F.
Lightly oil a baking pan.
Cut 1 plum tomato into 1/4-inch-thick slices.
Arrange tomato slices in one layer in the prepared pan.
Brush tomato slices with 0.33 teaspoon olive oil.
Roast tomatoes in the middle of the oven for 20 minutes, or until browned lightly, and keep warm.
Pat 1 lamb chop dry.
In a small dish, stir together 1 teaspoon ground cumin, 0.25 teaspoon coarse salt, and 0.25 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper.
Rub the spice mixture on both sides of the lamb chop.
In a 9-inch heavy non-stick skillet, heat 0.67 teaspoons olive oil over moderate heat until hot but not smoking.
Cook the lamb chop for 3 to 5 minutes on each side for medium-rare meat.
Transfer the lamb chop to a plate and serve with the roasted tomatoes.

original_instructions:
Pour the oil into a deep, heavy bottomed pot and heat to 350 degrees F.
Make the breading mixture by combining the breadcrumbs, and Parmesan in a medium bowl. Mix to blend. In another bowl, whisk together the eggs and the splash of water.
Place the zucchini in a large bowl and season with salt. Toss to blend. Sprinkle lightly with flour (use a sieve) to dredge then toss to coat evenly - this will help the breading to stick. Submerge the zucchini in the eggs. Remove the pieces, 1 by 1, shaking off excess egg and them roll them in the breadcrumb mixture until they are coated on all sides. Transfer to a platter or baking sheet.
When the oil comes up to temperature, test the oil by dropping in one piece of zucchini. It should rise to the surface fairly quickly, begin the bubble and fry gradually. Prepare a baking sheet fitted with a kitchen towel and a slotted spoon (or, alternatively, a spider) to remove the zucchini from the oil. Drop a few pieces of zucchini into the oil and gently swirl the oil as they fry. This swirling will allow the zucchini to move around a lot, assuring they fry more evenly on all sides. When they are light to medium brown, remove them with the spoon and lay them out on the kitchen towel to cool. Sprinkle with a touch of salt and paprika. Repeat.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges.
ingredients: 4 medium zucchini, washed, dried, ends trimmed, cut, lengthwise, into 10 wedges like pickles
step_by_step_instructions: Pour about 0.5 cups of canola oil into a deep, heavy bottomed pot and heat to 350 degrees F.
Make the breading mixture by combining about 0.125 cups of toasted Italian breadcrumbs and about 0.375 tablespoons of grated Parmesan in a medium bowl. Mix to blend.
In another bowl, whisk together 1 egg and a small splash of water.
Take 1 medium zucchini, wash, dry, trim the ends, and cut it lengthwise into 2 or 3 wedges like pickles.
Place the zucchini wedges in a large bowl and season with a pinch of salt. Toss to blend.
Sprinkle lightly about 0.5 cups of flour over the zucchini using a sieve to dredge, then toss to coat evenly.
Submerge the zucchini in the egg mixture.
Remove the zucchini pieces one by one, shaking off excess egg, then roll them in the breadcrumb mixture until they are coated on all sides.
Transfer the coated zucchini to a platter or baking sheet.
When the oil comes up to temperature, test the oil by dropping in one piece of zucchini. It should rise to the surface fairly quickly, begin to bubble, and fry gradually.
Prepare a baking sheet fitted with a kitchen towel and a slotted spoon to remove the zucchini from the oil.
Drop a few pieces of zucchini into the oil and gently swirl the oil as they fry.
When they are light to medium brown, remove them with the spoon and lay them out on the kitchen towel to cool.
Sprinkle with a touch of salt and about 0.125 tablespoons of paprika.
Serve immediately with a wedge of lemon.

original_instructions:
1. Heat oven to 375 degrees F.
2. Wash the turkey, inside and out, and dry well. Coat inside and outside with olive oil. Season turkey on the outside with salt and pepper, pressing it in to adhere. Place 2 rosemary sprigs, 1 thyme sprig, 1 sage sprig, 1 oregano sprig and lemon halves inside the cavity of the turkey. Place cooling rack or roasting rack in bottom of large roasting pan. Place turkey on rack, and arrange carrots, celery and remaining herbs on bottom of pan around turkey. Pour 4 cups (1 carton) chicken broth and water over vegetables and herbs.
3. Roast until an instant-read thermometer (inserted deep into the thigh but away from the bone) reads 165 degrees F and juices in the thigh run clear when pierced with a fork, about 2 to 2 1/2 hours, basting with pan broth every 30 minutes. Remove turkey from the pan and let rest for 15 minutes before carving. Strain and reserve pan juices, and discard vegetables.
4. While turkey is resting, make the gravy. In a medium heavy saucepan, cook flour and butter over medium heat for 3 to 4 minutes, or until a blond roux is formed. Add pan juices and 4 cups (1 carton) of chicken broth; heat to boiling over high heat. Reduce the heat and let simmer until thickened and ready to serve.
5. Carve turkey as desired, and serve with gravy.
Copyright 2010 Michael Chiarello
Recipe provided by Chef Michael Chiarello - June 2010.
ingredients: 2 cartons (32 oz each) Progresso chicken broth
step_by_step_instructions: 1. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees F.
2. Wash and dry the turkey thoroughly, inside and out.
3. Coat the turkey inside and out with approximately 0.23 tbsp of olive oil.
4. Season the outside of the turkey with about 0.08 tsp of salt and 0.04 tsp of freshly ground black pepper, pressing it in to adhere.
5. Place a small portion of rosemary, thyme, sage, and oregano along with 0.08 of a lemon inside the cavity of the turkey.
6. Place the turkey on a roasting rack in a pan, and arrange around 0.33 of a carrot, 0.67 of a celery stalk, and a small portion of the remaining herbs on the bottom of the pan.
7. Pour about 0.5 cups of chicken broth and 0.5 cups of water over the vegetables and herbs.
8. Roast the turkey in the oven, basting with pan broth every 30 minutes, until an instant-read thermometer reads 165 degrees F when inserted into the thigh, approximately 2 to 2.5 hours.
9. Remove the turkey from the pan and let it rest for 15 minutes before carving.
10. While the turkey is resting, strain and reserve the pan juices, discarding the vegetables.
11. In a medium saucepan, cook 0.08 cups of flour and 0.08 cups of butter over medium heat for 3 to 4 minutes to form a blond roux.
12. Add the reserved pan juices and about 0.5 cups of chicken broth to the roux; bring to a boil over high heat.
13. Reduce the heat and simmer until the gravy thickens, then serve with the carved turkey.

original_instructions:
Combine the garlic, ginger, chiles and 3 tablespoons kosher salt in a food processor and process to a fine paste; transfer the marinade to a large bowl. Using a paring knife, pierce each chicken wing two or three times through the skin then add to the marinade, tossing to coat evenly. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
Meanwhile, toast the coconut in a medium skillet over medium heat, stirring often until golden, 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer the coconut to a bowl and let cool.
Make the raita: Combine the cucumber and 1 teaspoon salt in colander set over a bowl, toss to combine and let stand for 30 minutes. Use your hands to squeeze as much moisture as possible from the cucumbers, then transfer them to a bowl. Stir in the yogurt, cilantro, lime zest and juice. Season the raita with more salt and pepper then cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate until ready to use, up to 2 days. Stir before serving.
Put the chickpea flour in a large bowl. Using tongs, remove half the wings from the marinade and toss with the flour to coat evenly. Transfer the wings to a wire rack set over a baking sheet and repeat the dredging process with the remaining wings. Discard any leftover chickpea flour.
Heat 2 inches of oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat until a deep-fry thermometer registers 350 degrees F. Working in 2 batches, fry the wings, turning occasionally, until golden brown and cooked through, 16 to 18 minutes per batch. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the wings to a large bowl and sprinkle with salt. (Make sure the oil returns to the proper temperature between batches.)
Toast the mustard and coriander seeds in a medium skillet over medium heat, swirling the pan until the mustard seeds begin to pop and the spices are fragrant, 2 to 3 minutes. Stir in the turmeric, cook for 10 seconds, then stir in the butter. Heat until the butter melts and the spices begin to sizzle, about 1 minute. Pour the butter and spices over the chicken wings, toss to coat, then transfer to a serving platter. Add the toasted coconut to the seasonings left in the large bowl, then sprinkle over the wings. Serve immediately with the raita on the side.
ingredients: 2 heads garlic, cloves separated and peeled
One 8-inch piece ginger (about 6 ounces), peeled and thinly sliced
10 serrano chiles (about 4 ounces), stems removed (remove seeds for less heat)
4 pounds chicken wings, separated into flats and drummettes
1 cucumber, grated on the large holes of a box grater
Finely grated zest and juice of 1 lime
step_by_step_instructions: Combine 0.25 heads garlic, 0.25 ounce ginger, 0.25 serrano chiles, and 0.38 teaspoon kosher salt in a food processor and process to a fine paste. Transfer the marinade to a large bowl.

Pierce 0.5 pound chicken wings two or three times through the skin and add to the marinade, tossing to coat evenly. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
Toast 0.13 cup sweetened shredded coconut in a medium skillet over medium heat, stirring often until golden, about 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer the coconut to a bowl and let cool.

Make the raita by combining 0.13 cucumber and 0.13 teaspoon salt in a colander set over a bowl. Toss to combine and let stand for 30 minutes. Squeeze out as much moisture as possible from the cucumbers, then transfer them to a bowl.

Stir in 0.13 cup plain whole-milk yogurt, 0.25 tablespoon finely chopped cilantro, and 0.13 lime's zest and juice. Season the raita with more salt and pepper, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate until ready to use, up to 2 days. Stir before serving.

Put 0.38 cup chickpea flour in a large bowl. Using tongs, remove 0.25 pound wings from the marinade and toss with the flour to coat evenly. Transfer the wings to a wire rack set over a baking sheet. Discard any leftover chickpea flour.
Heat 2 inches of oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat until a deep-fry thermometer registers 350 degrees F.

Working in batches, fry the wings, turning occasionally, until golden brown and cooked through, about 16 to 18 minutes per batch. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the wings to a large bowl and sprinkle with salt.

Toast 0.25 tablespoon mustard seeds and 0.25 tablespoon coriander seeds in a medium skillet over medium heat, swirling the pan until the mustard seeds begin to pop and the spices are fragrant, about 2 to 3 minutes.
Stir in 0.03 teaspoon ground turmeric and cook for 10 seconds, then stir in 1 tablespoon unsalted butter. Heat until the butter melts and the spices begin to sizzle, about 1 minute.
Pour the butter and spices over the chicken wings, toss to coat, then transfer to a serving platter.
Add the toasted coconut to the seasonings left in the large bowl, then sprinkle over the wings. Serve immediately with the raita on the side.

original_instructions:
Bring clams and 4 cups water to a boil in a large pot over high heat. Cook until clams just open, 8-10 minutes (discard any that do not open). Using a large slotted spoon, transfer clams to a large rimmed baking sheet; set broth aside. Let clams cool slightly, then pull meat from shells; discard shells. Chop clams into bite-size pieces. Strain broth through a fine-mesh sieve set over a large bowl. Add water if needed to measure 6 cups. DO AHEAD: Clams and broth can be made 1 day ahead. Cover separately and chill. Melt butter in a large heavy pot over medium heat. Add bacon and cook, stirring occasionally, until fat is rendered and bacon begins to brown, about 8 minutes. Add celery, onion, and garlic and cook, stirring often, until onion is translucent, about 10 minutes. Add reserved broth (or 6 cups bottled clam juice), potatoes, thyme, and bay leaf. Bring chowder base to a simmer; cook until potatoes are tender, 20-25 minutes. Stir cornstarch and 2 Tbsp. water in a small bowl to form a slurry. Stir slurry into chowder base; return to a boil to thicken. DO AHEAD: Base can be made 1 day ahead. Let cool; cover and chill. Keep clams chilled. Bring base to a simmer before continuing. Remove base from heat. Discard bay leaf. Stir in reserved clams (or two 10-ounce cans baby clams) and cream. Season with salt, if needed (clams' brininess varies), and pepper. Divide chowder among bowls. Garnish with chives and oyster crackers.
Bring clams and 4 cups water to a boil in a large pot over high heat. Cook until clams just open, 8-10 minutes (discard any that do not open). Using a large slotted spoon, transfer clams to a large rimmed baking sheet; set broth aside. Let clams cool slightly, then pull meat from shells; discard shells.
Chop clams into bite-size pieces. Strain broth through a fine-mesh sieve set over a large bowl. Add water if needed to measure 6 cups. DO AHEAD: Clams and broth can be made 1 day ahead. Cover separately and chill.
Melt butter in a large heavy pot over medium heat. Add bacon and cook, stirring occasionally, until fat is rendered and bacon begins to brown, about 8 minutes. Add celery, onion, and garlic and cook, stirring often, until onion is translucent, about 10 minutes. Add reserved broth (or 6 cups bottled clam juice), potatoes, thyme, and bay leaf. Bring chowder base to a simmer; cook until potatoes are tender, 20-25 minutes. Stir cornstarch and 2 Tbsp. water in a small bowl to form a slurry. Stir slurry into chowder base; return to a boil to thicken. DO AHEAD: Base can be made 1 day ahead. Let cool; cover and chill. Keep clams chilled. Bring base to a simmer before continuing.
Remove base from heat. Discard bay leaf. Stir in reserved clams (or two 10-ounce cans baby clams) and cream. Season with salt, if needed (clams' brininess varies), and pepper.
Divide chowder among bowls. Garnish with chives and oyster crackers.
ingredients: 2 1/2 pound Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled, cut into 1/2" pieces
Oyster crackers or Vermont Common Crackers
step_by_step_instructions: Bring 0.5 pounds of cherrystone clams and 0.5 cups of water to a boil in a large pot over high heat.
Cook until clams just open, about 8-10 minutes, discarding any that do not open.
Using a large slotted spoon, transfer clams to a large rimmed baking sheet; set broth aside.
Let clams cool slightly, then pull meat from shells and discard shells.
Chop clams into bite-size pieces.
Strain broth through a fine-mesh sieve set over a large bowl. Add water if needed to measure 0.75 cups.
Melt 0.06 tablespoons of unsalted butter in a large heavy pot over medium heat.
Add 0.5 ounces of bacon, cut into 1/2" pieces, and cook, stirring occasionally, until fat is rendered and bacon begins to brown, about 8 minutes.
Add 0.25 minced celery stalks, 0.125 minced large onion, and 0.125 minced garlic clove and cook, stirring often, until onion is translucent, about 10 minutes.
Add reserved broth, 0.31 pounds of Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled, cut into 1/2" pieces, 0.06 tablespoons of chopped fresh thyme, and 0.125 bay leaf.
Bring chowder base to a simmer and cook until potatoes are tender, 20-25 minutes.
Stir 0.13 tablespoons of cornstarch and 0.13 tablespoons of water in a small bowl to form a slurry.
Stir slurry into chowder base; return to a boil to thicken.
Remove base from heat and discard bay leaf.
Stir in reserved clams and 0.25 cups of heavy cream.
Season with kosher salt and freshly ground pepper to taste.
Divide chowder among bowls.
Garnish with chopped fresh chives and oyster crackers.

original_instructions:
Rub each chicken half all over with 2 tablespoons oil, then 1 1/2 teaspoons pepper. Sprinkle generously with salt. Let stand at room temperature 1 hour. Preheat broiler. Arrange chicken, skin side down, on broiler pan. Watching closely to avoid burning, broil chicken 5 to 6 inches from heat source until golden brown, about 12 minutes. Remove broiler pan from oven. Using tongs, transfer chicken to plate. Pour off any pan drippings. Return chicken, skin side up, to broiler pan. Broil until skin is crisp and golden brown, about 5 minutes. Turn chicken over, skin side down again, and broil until cooked through, about 8 minutes longer. Transfer chicken to platter; let stand 5 minutes. Serve with lemon wedges to squeeze over
Rub each chicken half all over with 2 tablespoons oil, then 1 1/2 teaspoons pepper. Sprinkle generously with salt. Let stand at room temperature 1 hour.
Preheat broiler. Arrange chicken, skin side down, on broiler pan. Watching closely to avoid burning, broil chicken 5 to 6 inches from heat source until golden brown, about 12 minutes. Remove broiler pan from oven. Using tongs, transfer chicken to plate. Pour off any pan drippings. Return chicken, skin side up, to broiler pan. Broil until skin is crisp and golden brown, about 5 minutes. Turn chicken over, skin side down again, and broil until cooked through, about 8 minutes longer. Transfer chicken to platter; let stand 5 minutes. Serve with lemon wedges to squeeze over
ingredients: 2 3 1/2-pound chickens, halved, backbones removed, excess fat trimmed
step_by_step_instructions: Rub each chicken half all over with 1 tablespoon of oil and 0.38 teaspoon of pepper.
Sprinkle generously with salt.
Let stand at room temperature for 1 hour.
Preheat broiler.
Arrange chicken, skin side down, on broiler pan.
Broil chicken 5 to 6 inches from heat source until golden brown, about 12 minutes.
Remove broiler pan from oven.
Using tongs, transfer chicken to plate.
Pour off any pan drippings.
Return chicken, skin side up, to broiler pan.
Broil until skin is crisp and golden brown, about 5 minutes.
Turn chicken over, skin side down again, and broil until cooked through, about 8 minutes longer.
Transfer chicken to platter; let stand 5 minutes.
Serve with lemon wedges to squeeze over.

recipe_title: Toasted Orzo with Peas, Onion and Bacon
original_instructions:
Heat large nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add orzo and stir until beginning to color, about 10 minutes. Transfer orzo to small bowl. Add onion and bacon to same skillet. Sauté until bacon browns and onion is tender, about 15 minutes. Add 3 1/4 cups broth and orzo and bring to boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover and simmer until broth is absorbed and orzo is tender, about 18 minutes. Mix in peas. Add more broth if mixture is dry. Cover and cook until peas are just warmed through, about 2 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve.
Heat large nonstick skillet over medium heat. Add orzo and stir until beginning to color, about 10 minutes. Transfer orzo to small bowl. Add onion and bacon to same skillet. Sauté until bacon browns and onion is tender, about 15 minutes. Add 3 1/4 cups broth and orzo and bring to boil. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover and simmer until broth is absorbed and orzo is tender, about 18 minutes. Mix in peas. Add more broth if mixture is dry. Cover and cook until peas are just warmed through, about 2 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve.
ingredients: 3 1/4 cups (or more) canned low-salt chicken broth
step_by_step_instructions: Heat a nonstick skillet over medium heat.
Add approximately 0.25 cups of orzo and stir until beginning to color, about 10 minutes.
Transfer orzo to a small bowl.
Add about 0.31 cups of chopped onion and 1 slice of chopped bacon to the same skillet.
Sauté until bacon browns and onion is tender, about 15 minutes.
Add 0.54 cups of chicken broth and the orzo to the skillet and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer until broth is absorbed and orzo is tender, about 18 minutes.
Mix in approximately 0.25 cups of thawed peas.
Add more broth if mixture is dry.
Cover and cook until peas are just warmed through, about 2 minutes.
Season to taste with salt and pepper, then serve.

original_instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F. Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil and set a wire rack on top; coat with cooking spray. Combine 1 cup water, the coconut water, rice and lime zest in a medium saucepan and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium low; cover and simmer 8 minutes. Remove from the heat; add the carrots, red onion, 1/4 teaspoon salt and a few grinds of pepper (do not stir). Cover and let sit 10 minutes, then fluff with a fork to combine. Discard the lime zest.
Meanwhile, season the shrimp with salt and pepper. Beat the egg and 2 tablespoons water in a bowl. Combine the coconut and panko in another bowl. Dip the shrimp in the egg mixture, then the coconut-panko mixture, gently pressing to adhere; transfer to the prepared rack. Bake until the shrimp are cooked through, about 10 minutes.
Turn on the broiler. Broil the shrimp until golden brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the cilantro to the rice mixture and toss. Serve with the shrimp and lime wedges.
Photograph by Charles Masters
ingredients: 3/4 cup jasmati or other long-grain rice
Zest of 1 lime (removed with a vegetable peeler), plus wedges for serving
2 tablespoons finely chopped red onion or scallions
Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper
1 pound large shrimp, peeled and deveined
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F.
Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil and set a wire rack on top; coat with cooking spray.
Combine 0.13 cups water, 0.13 cups coconut water, 0.13 cups rice, and zest from a small piece of lime in a medium saucepan and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to medium low; cover and simmer for 8 minutes.
Remove from the heat; add 0.08 cups shredded carrots, 0.03 cups finely chopped red onion, 0.04 tsp salt, and a few grinds of pepper without stirring.
Cover and let sit for 10 minutes, then fluff with a fork to combine. Discard the lime zest.
Meanwhile, season 0.17 pounds of shrimp with salt and pepper.
Beat 0.25 large egg and 0.33 tablespoons water in a bowl.
Combine 0.17 cups sweetened shredded coconut and 0.13 cups panko breadcrumbs in another bowl.
Dip the shrimp in the egg mixture, then the coconut-panko mixture, gently pressing to adhere; transfer to the prepared rack.
Bake until the shrimp are cooked through, about 10 minutes.
Turn on the broiler. Broil the shrimp until golden brown, 1 to 2 minutes.
Add 0.33 tablespoons chopped cilantro to the rice mixture and toss.
Serve with the shrimp and a lime wedge.

recipe_title: Rosemary, Lemon, and Garlic Leg of Lamb with Roasted Potatoes
original_instructions:
Preheat oven to 350°F. Cut off and discard pith from zested lemon and cut off and discard zest and pith from other lemon. In a saucepan of boiling water blanch zest 1 minute and drain in a colander. Cut each lemon crosswise into 6 slices. In a small food processor blend rosemary, garlic, zest, 1 tablespoon oil, lemon juice, and salt until mixture is chopped fine. With tip of a small sharp knife cut small slits all over lamb and rub rosemary mixture over lamb, rubbing into slits. Arrange lemon slices in middle of a large roasting pan and arrange lamb on them. Roast lamb in middle of oven 45 minutes. Quarter potatoes and in a saucepan cover with salted cold water by 1 inch. Bring water to a boil and cook potatoes, covered, 5 minutes. Drain potatoes in colander and in a bowl toss with remaining tablespoon oil. Arrange potatoes around lamb and sprinkle with salt and pepper to taste. Roast lamb and potatoes, stirring potatoes occasionally, 55 minutes, or until a meat thermometer registers 140°F. for medium-rare. Transfer lamb to a cutting board and let stand 15 minutes. Increase temperature to 500°F. and roast potatoes and lemons in one layer 5 to 10 minutes more, or until golden. Transfer potatoes and lemons with a slotted spoon to bowl and toss with chives. Transfer potato mixture to a platter. Serve lamb, sliced thin across grain, with potatoes, garnished with rosemary and lemon wedges.
Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cut off and discard pith from zested lemon and cut off and discard zest and pith from other lemon. In a saucepan of boiling water blanch zest 1 minute and drain in a colander. Cut each lemon crosswise into 6 slices.
In a small food processor blend rosemary, garlic, zest, 1 tablespoon oil, lemon juice, and salt until mixture is chopped fine.
With tip of a small sharp knife cut small slits all over lamb and rub rosemary mixture over lamb, rubbing into slits. Arrange lemon slices in middle of a large roasting pan and arrange lamb on them. Roast lamb in middle of oven 45 minutes.
Quarter potatoes and in a saucepan cover with salted cold water by 1 inch. Bring water to a boil and cook potatoes, covered, 5 minutes. Drain potatoes in colander and in a bowl toss with remaining tablespoon oil. Arrange potatoes around lamb and sprinkle with salt and pepper to taste.
Roast lamb and potatoes, stirring potatoes occasionally, 55 minutes, or until a meat thermometer registers 140°F. for medium-rare. Transfer lamb to a cutting board and let stand 15 minutes. Increase temperature to 500°F. and roast potatoes and lemons in one layer 5 to 10 minutes more, or until golden. Transfer potatoes and lemons with a slotted spoon to bowl and toss with chives. Transfer potato mixture to a platter.
Serve lamb, sliced thin across grain, with potatoes, garnished with rosemary and lemon wedges.
ingredients: 2 large lemons, zest of 1 removed in strips with a vegetable peeler
a 7-pound leg of lamb (ask butcher to remove pelvic bone and tie lamb for easier carving)
Garnish: fresh rosemary sprigs and lemon wedges
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cut off and discard pith from zested lemon and cut off and discard zest and pith from other lemon.
In a saucepan of boiling water, blanch zest 1 minute and drain in a colander.
Cut each lemon crosswise into 6 slices.
In a small food processor, blend rosemary, garlic, zest, 0.17 tablespoon oil, lemon juice, and salt until mixture is chopped fine.
With the tip of a small sharp knife, cut small slits all over 1 pound of lamb.
Rub rosemary mixture over lamb, rubbing into slits.
Arrange 2 lemon slices in the middle of a large roasting pan and arrange lamb on them.
Roast lamb in the middle of the oven for 45 minutes.
Quarter 0.36 pounds of potatoes and in a saucepan cover with salted cold water by 1 inch.
Bring water to a boil and cook potatoes, covered, for 5 minutes.
Drain potatoes in a colander and in a bowl toss with 0.17 tablespoon oil.
Arrange potatoes around lamb and sprinkle with salt and pepper to taste.
Roast lamb and potatoes, stirring potatoes occasionally, for 55 minutes, or until a meat thermometer registers 140°F for medium-rare.
Transfer lamb to a cutting board and let stand for 15 minutes.
Increase oven temperature to 500°F and roast potatoes and lemons in one layer for 5 to 10 minutes more, or until golden.
Transfer potatoes and lemons with a slotted spoon to a bowl and toss with 0.5 tablespoons chives.
Transfer potato mixture to a platter.
Serve lamb, sliced thin across grain, with potatoes, garnished with rosemary and lemon wedges.

recipe_title: Mushroom and Cheddar Fritatta and Arugula Side Salad
original_instructions:
Preheat the broiler and set the rack about 4 to 5 inches from the heat source.
Heat oil in large ovenproof nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Saute mushrooms until browned, seasoning with salt and pepper. Add onion and saute until tender.
Whisk eggs, egg whites, salt, and pepper in a medium bowl. Pour over vegetables in skillet and mix gently. Reduce heat to medium-low, cover skillet, and cook until eggs are set around edges, about 4 to 5 minutes. Sprinkle with cheese and then place skillet under broiler and cook until cheese is melted and just browned, about 2 minutes. Let frittata stand 1 minute before cutting into 8 wedges. Serve with salad on the side.
Arugula Salad:
1 large bunch arugula leaves, washed and dried
1/4 cup olive oil
1 lemon, juiced
10 grinds black pepper
Couple pinches salt
Combine all ingredients in a large bowl. Toss to coat leaves with dressing and serve with the frittata.
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat the broiler and set the rack about 4 to 5 inches from the heat source.
Heat 0.38 tablespoon vegetable oil in a large ovenproof nonstick skillet over medium-high heat.
Saute 1.25 ounces mushrooms until browned, seasoning with salt and pepper.
Add 0.13 medium onion, chopped, and saute until tender.
Whisk 1 egg, 0.5 egg whites with a pinch of salt and pepper in a medium bowl.
Pour the egg mixture over the vegetables in the skillet and mix gently.
Reduce heat to medium-low, cover the skillet, and cook until eggs are set around the edges, about 4 to 5 minutes.
Sprinkle 0.13 cup grated sharp Cheddar over the eggs.
Place the skillet under the broiler and cook until the cheese is melted and just browned, about 2 minutes.
Let the frittata stand 1 minute before cutting into 1 wedge.
For the salad, combine 0.13 large bunch arugula leaves, 0.03 cup olive oil, juice of 0.13 lemon, 1 grind black pepper, and a pinch of salt in a large bowl.
Toss to coat leaves with dressing and serve with the frittata.

original_instructions:
Cook the bacon in a medium cast-iron skillet over medium heat, flipping about halfway through, until crisp and the fat has rendered, about 8 minutes; transfer to a plate. Pour off and reserve the bacon drippings, leaving enough in the skillet to coat it nicely.
Slice 4 rounded chunks of lettuce (4 to 5 inches across) from the top and 3 sides of the head to make "bun" halves; set on a platter.
Shape the ground beef into 2 burgers, each about 4 inches wide and 3/4 inch thick, and sprinkle both sides with salt and pepper. Put the bacon skillet over high heat, add the burgers and cook for 3 minutes; flip and cook for 3 minutes more for medium rare.
Lay 1 lettuce "bun" half cut-side up on each of 2 plates and top with a burger. Spoon 1 tablespoon of the dressing over each burger and top with 1 tablespoon of the onion. Crumble 1 piece of bacon over each burger and top with the remaining lettuce "bun" tops.
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
step_by_step_instructions: Cook 1 slice of bacon in a medium cast-iron skillet over medium heat, flipping halfway through, until crisp and the fat has rendered, about 4 minutes; transfer to a plate.
Pour off and reserve the bacon drippings, leaving enough in the skillet to coat it nicely.
Slice 2 rounded chunks of lettuce (4 to 5 inches across) from the head to make "bun" halves; set on a platter.
Shape 5 ounces of ground beef into a burger, about 4 inches wide and 3/4 inch thick, and sprinkle both sides with salt and pepper.
Put the bacon skillet over high heat, add the burger and cook for 3 minutes; flip and cook for 3 minutes more for medium rare.
Lay 1 lettuce "bun" half cut-side up on a plate and top with the burger.
Spoon 1 tablespoon of the dressing over the burger and top with 1 tablespoon of the onion.
Crumble the bacon over the burger and top with the remaining lettuce "bun" top.

recipe_title: Chicken, Black Bean and Goat Cheese Toastadas
original_instructions:
Make beans: Heat olive oil in heavy medium saucepan over medium-low heat. Add onion and chilies; cook until onion is translucent, stirring occasionally, about 8 minutes. Add chili powder and cumin; stir 30 seconds. Add beans and lime juice. Cook until heat through, stirring and mashing beans slightly with spoon, about 4 minutes. (Can be prepared 1 day ahead. Cover and chill.)
Heat olive oil in heavy medium saucepan over medium-low heat. Add onion and chilies; cook until onion is translucent, stirring occasionally, about 8 minutes. Add chili powder and cumin; stir 30 seconds. Add beans and lime juice. Cook until heat through, stirring and mashing beans slightly with spoon, about 4 minutes. (Can be prepared 1 day ahead. Cover and chill.)
Make chicken: Heat oil in heavy large skillet over high heat. Add chicken and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Stir until almost cooked through, about 3 minutes. Add chili powder and cumin and stir until cooked through, about 30 seconds. Remove from heat.
Heat oil in heavy large skillet over high heat. Add chicken and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Stir until almost cooked through, about 3 minutes. Add chili powder and cumin and stir until cooked through, about 30 seconds. Remove from heat.
Make Salad: Combine first 3 ingredients in large bowl. Add oil to depth of 1/4 inch to heavy medium skillet. Heat over medium-high heat until just beginning to smoke. Add tortilla and cook until crisp, abut 30 seconds per side. Drain on paper towels. Repeat with remaining tortillas. Add 1/4 cup olive oil to salad; toss Season with salt and pepper. Add 1 tablespoon lime juice; toss. Rewarm beans over medium-low heat, stirring and thinning slightly with water. Place 1 tortilla on each plate. Spread with beans. Sprinkle with cheese. Top with salad, then chicken, salsa and cilantro.
Combine first 3 ingredients in large bowl.
Add oil to depth of 1/4 inch to heavy medium skillet. Heat over medium-high heat until just beginning to smoke. Add tortilla and cook until crisp, abut 30 seconds per side. Drain on paper towels. Repeat with remaining tortillas.
Add 1/4 cup olive oil to salad; toss Season with salt and pepper. Add 1 tablespoon lime juice; toss. Rewarm beans over medium-low heat, stirring and thinning slightly with water. Place 1 tortilla on each plate. Spread with beans. Sprinkle with cheese. Top with salad, then chicken, salsa and cilantro.
ingredients: 2 large jalapeño chilies, seeded but not deveined, minced
1 1/2 pounds boneless chicken breasts, skinned, cut into 3/4-inch pieces
step_by_step_instructions: Heat 0.33 tablespoon olive oil in a heavy medium saucepan over medium-low heat.
Add 0.17 red onion (chopped) and 0.33 jalapeño chili (minced) and cook until the onion is translucent, stirring occasionally, about 8 minutes.
Add 0.17 teaspoon chili powder and 0.08 teaspoon ground cumin and stir for 30 seconds.
Add 5.33 ounces black beans and 1 teaspoon fresh lime juice. Cook until heated through, stirring and mashing beans slightly with a spoon, about 4 minutes. Set aside.
Heat 0.33 tablespoon olive oil in a heavy large skillet over high heat.
Add 0.25 pound boneless chicken breast (cut into 3/4-inch pieces), sprinkle with salt and pepper, and stir until almost cooked through, about 3 minutes.
Add 0.25 teaspoon chili powder and 0.13 teaspoon ground cumin and stir until cooked through, about 30 seconds. Remove from heat.
In a large bowl, combine 0.67 cup sliced romaine lettuce, 0.17 medium head radicchio (sliced), and 0.08 cup fresh cilantro leaves.
Add oil to a depth of 1/4 inch to a heavy medium skillet. Heat over medium-high heat until just beginning to smoke.
Add 1 corn tortilla and cook until crisp, about 30 seconds per side. Drain on paper towels.
Add 1 tablespoon olive oil to the salad, toss, then season with salt and pepper.
Add 0.17 tablespoon fresh lime juice to the salad and toss.
Rewarm the beans over medium-low heat, stirring and thinning slightly with water if necessary.
Place 1 tortilla on a plate. Spread with beans, sprinkle with 1.33 ounces goat cheese, top with salad, then chicken, avocado salsa, and a sprig of fresh cilantro.

original_instructions:
For the potatoes: Steam the potatoes in a covered saucepan with about 1 inch/2.5 cm water in the bottom, until very tender, about 30 minutes.
For the mushrooms: Clean and quarter the mushrooms. Heat just 2 tablespoons of the butter with 1 tablespoon of the olive oil and saute the mushrooms until cooked and golden. Remove from the pan. Heat the other spoonful of olive oil (adding more if you need it) and saute the onion until soft. Add the garlic for 1 minute. Deglaze with the wine and reduce to no more than a spoonful. Add the stock, thyme and mushrooms, season with salt and pepper and cook until the stock has reduced by half. Knead together the flour with the last tablespoon of butter and stir it in. Cook until the liquid has thickened to a sauce, a matter of minutes. Stir in the parsley. Spoon the mixture into a gratin dish.
For the cheese potato top: Heat the oven to 425 degrees F/220 degrees C. Mash the potatoes with the milk and butter until smooth, adding more milk if needed. Season with salt and pepper. Stir in the diced cheese. Distribute evenly over the mushroom mixture, and smooth with the back of the spoon (if you want to be very retro-housewife, make patterns with the tines of a fork or make waves with a spoon). Sprinkle over the Parmesan. Bake the gratin until bubbling hot and golden on top, about 15 minutes.
ingredients: 6 medium floury potatoes, such as Yukon gold
2 tablespoons olive oil, more as needed
1/2 cup/125 ml vegetable stock or water
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper
4 ounces/110 g Comte or Gruyere cheese, cut into very fine dice
step_by_step_instructions: Steam 1 medium potato in a covered saucepan with about 0.16 cup water in the bottom until very tender, about 30 minutes.
Clean and quarter 0.33 pound mushrooms.
Heat 0.5 tablespoon butter with 0.16 tablespoon olive oil in a pan and sauté the mushrooms until cooked and golden. Remove from the pan.
Heat an additional 0.16 tablespoon olive oil in the pan (adding more if needed) and sauté 0.16 of a large red onion until soft.
Add 0.5 minced garlic clove and cook for 1 minute.
Deglaze the pan with 0.08 cup red wine and reduce it to no more than a spoonful.
Add 0.08 cup vegetable stock, a pinch of thyme, and the mushrooms back into the pan. Season with salt and pepper and cook until the stock has reduced by half.
Knead 0.16 tablespoon flour with 0.16 tablespoon butter and stir it into the pan. Cook until the liquid has thickened to a sauce.
Stir in a small pinch of parsley and spoon the mixture into a small gratin dish.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F/220 degrees C.
Mash the steamed potato with 0.04 cup milk and 0.5 tablespoon butter until smooth, adding more milk if needed. Season with salt and pepper.
Stir in 0.66 ounce diced Comte or Gruyere cheese.
Distribute the mashed potato evenly over the mushroom mixture in the gratin dish and smooth the top with the back of a spoon.
Sprinkle 0.33 tablespoon grated Parmesan over the top.
Bake the gratin until bubbling hot and golden on top, about 15 minutes.

original_instructions:
Special equipment: A small roasting pan and rack, butcher's twine
Pat the chicken dry inside and out with paper towels, and let sit at room temperature to take the chill off, about 30 minutes. Meanwhile, position an oven rack in the center of the oven, and preheat to 450 degrees F. Put a rack in a small roasting pan.
Season the cavity of the chicken generously with salt and pepper, and stuff it with the thyme and garlic. Tie the legs together with butcher's twine. Season the outside with salt (generously) and a few grinds of pepper, and place the chicken breast-side up on the rack. (Seasoning the chicken when on the rack could result in gravy that's too salty.)
Roast the chicken until the skin is golden brown and crispy and a thermometer inserted in the deepest part of the thigh registers 165 to 170 degrees F, depending on how you like your dark meat, 50 minutes to 1 hour. Let the chicken rest on the rack for a few minutes, then carefully tip it forward to drain all the collected juices into the roasting pan. Discard the thyme and garlic. Let the chicken rest on a cutting board while you make the gravy. (To transfer the chicken easily, hold a wooden spoon handle in the cavity with one hand and use the other hand to lift the chicken with tongs.)
Remove the rack from the pan, and pour the pan drippings into a small bowl. Skim off 2 tablespoons of the fat, and stir them into the flour and 2 tablespoons water in another small bowl. Heat the roasting pan over medium-high heat, add the wine, scrape up any browned bits and simmer until the wine reduces by half, 3 to 4 minutes. Add the chicken stock and any remaining pan drippings, bring to a simmer, add the flour mixture and whisk constantly until the liquid thickens into a gravy, 2 to 3 minutes. Season the gravy with salt and pepper.
Remove the butcher's twine from the chicken. Snip off the wingtips using kitchen shears; reserve to make stock. Remove the leg quarters by slicing between the thigh and the body, then finding the hip joints near the backbone and slicing through them. Separate the drumsticks and thighs, and transfer to a platter. Sit the carcass upright; snip out the backbone and reserve it to make stock. Lay the breast skin-side up and slice in half through the breastbone. Separate the wings and breast, and transfer to the platter. Serve the chicken with the warm gravy. Reserve the carcass to make stock.
ingredients: One 4- to 5-pound chicken, giblets removed and reserved for another use
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
2 cups homemade chicken stock or low-sodium chicken broth
step_by_step_instructions: Pat the chicken dry inside and out with paper towels.
Let the chicken sit at room temperature for 30 minutes to take the chill off.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F and position the rack in the center.
Season the cavity of the chicken with salt and pepper.
Stuff the chicken with 1 sprig of thyme and 1 clove of garlic.
Tie the legs together with butcher's twine.
Season the outside of the chicken with salt and pepper.
Place the chicken breast-side up on a rack in a small roasting pan.
Roast the chicken for 50 minutes to 1 hour, until the skin is golden brown and crispy and a thermometer inserted in the deepest part of the thigh registers 165 to 170 degrees F.
Let the chicken rest on the rack for a few minutes.
Carefully tip the chicken forward to drain the juices into the roasting pan.
Discard the thyme and garlic.
Let the chicken rest on a cutting board while making the gravy.
Remove the rack from the pan and pour the pan drippings into a small bowl.
Skim off 2 tablespoons of the fat.
Stir the fat into 2 teaspoons of flour and 2 teaspoons of water in another small bowl.
Heat the roasting pan over medium-high heat and add 1/4 cup of wine.
Scrape up any browned bits and simmer until the wine reduces by half, about 3 minutes.
Add 1/2 cup of chicken stock and any remaining pan drippings.
Bring to a simmer and add the flour mixture.
Whisk constantly until the liquid thickens into a gravy, about 2 minutes.
Season the gravy with salt and pepper.
Remove the butcher's twine from the chicken.
Snip off the wingtips and reserve.
Remove the leg quarters by slicing between the thigh and the body, then find the hip joints near the backbone and slice through them.
Separate the drumsticks and thighs and transfer to a platter.
Sit the carcass upright and snip out the backbone to reserve.
Lay the breast skin-side up and slice in half through the breastbone.
Separate the wings and breast and transfer to the platter.
Serve the chicken with the warm gravy.

original_instructions:
Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 450°F. Butter 1 large baking sheet. Whisk together flour, cornmeal, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a bowl, then blend in butter with your fingertips or a pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse meal. Stir in cheeses and scallions with a wooden spoon, then add buttermilk and stir until just combined. Drop dough in 8 equal mounds about 2 inches apart on baking sheet. Bake until golden, about 15 minutes. Transfer to a rack and cool to warm, about 10 minutes, then cut in half horizontally.
Put oven rack in middle position and preheat oven to 450°F. Butter 1 large baking sheet.
Whisk together flour, cornmeal, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a bowl, then blend in butter with your fingertips or a pastry blender until mixture resembles coarse meal. Stir in cheeses and scallions with a wooden spoon, then add buttermilk and stir until just combined.
Drop dough in 8 equal mounds about 2 inches apart on baking sheet. Bake until golden, about 15 minutes. Transfer to a rack and cool to warm, about 10 minutes, then cut in half horizontally.
ingredients: 1/2 stick (1/4 cup) cold unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes
6 oz extra-sharp Cheddar, coarsely grated (2 cups)
step_by_step_instructions: Preheat the oven to 450°F and butter a large baking sheet.
In a bowl, whisk together 0.22 cups of all-purpose flour, 0.09 cups of cornmeal, 0.5 teaspoons of baking powder, 0.12 teaspoons of baking soda, and 0.12 teaspoons of salt.
Blend in 0.5 tablespoons of cold unsalted butter with your fingertips or a pastry blender until the mixture resembles coarse meal.
Stir in 0.75 ounces of coarsely grated extra-sharp Cheddar, 0.38 tablespoons of finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, and 0.38 scallions, finely chopped.
Add 0.17 cups of well-shaken buttermilk and stir until just combined.
Drop the dough in 1 equal mound on the baking sheet.
Bake until golden, about 15 minutes.
Transfer to a rack and cool to warm, about 10 minutes.
Cut in half horizontally.
